posts.name: Adam Aptowitz
posts.cooked:
Hello! My team is having loop overruns and we can’t figure out why it’s happening. We’ve tried using VisualVM to figure out what’s hogging our CPU. SmartDashboard.updateValues() seems to be using the largest amount of CPU time according to VisualVM (about 47%), so we don’t think that it’s our own user code. We have our own class to log loop times of robotPeriodic as well as our other subsystems (vision, swerve, etc.) with AdvantageKit, and it shows that our loop times rarely, if ever go above 20 ms.

Snapshot_2025-06-26_15-15-04 1920×1080 180 KB Snapshot_2025-06-26_15-40-19 1920×1008 211 KB

Snapshot_2025-06-26_15-15-04 1920×1080 180 KB

Snapshot_2025-06-26_15-15-04 1920×1080 180 KB

Snapshot_2025-06-26_15-40-19 1920×1008 211 KB

Snapshot_2025-06-26_15-40-19 1920×1008 211 KB

But we still get loop overruns in the console like this

And other ones every so often that look like this

For reference, our two subsystems that take up the largest share of CPU time according to VisualVM are swerve and vision. We are using PhotonVision.

What might be causing all these overruns? Is there even something we can do to fix these? Here’s a link to our GitHub repository . Note that this is on our better-controls branch, which seems to have no subsystem overruns as far as I’m aware. There might be some issues on main as well. I’ll also attach the most recent log file as well as some VisualVM snapshots if you want to take a look.

Akit Logs.zip (2.9 MB)

posts.name: Ethan Grieshop
posts.cooked:
Those loop overruns are really small. As long as they aren’t causing significant issues, it might be best to just ignore them.

Have you noticed any strange behavior because of these overruns or are you trying to get rid of the warning message?

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked: I couldn’t quickly analyze your code so a generalization from my teams experience: If there are many SmartDashboard outputs for human consumption, then my team displays once every 10 or more iterations. That has greatly reduced overruns for us.

Yeah, a continuation of this post, our elevator would violently jitter and shake and we have removed the RT thread prioritization to no avail. I will try to get a video for you but yeah, this is pretty much it. I did try to run the elevator PID on the TalonFX directly and it worked fine without the weird jitter, which would not be affected by the overruns.

The weird issue is that we don’t use SmartDashboard at all. I used to have two instances of it being called, which I later removed, putData, but that was correctly put in a constructor and not in a periodic function which is known to cause overruns.

posts.name: Karl Olson
posts.cooked: Is there a reason you prefer to run the elevator PID on the RIO? It is generally a good idea to offload the PID to a higher frequency controller (TalonFX runs at 1 kHz for comparison). 50 Hz is just not very good for PID of many subsystems in FRC .

posts.name: Tim Winters
posts.cooked:
olsonkarlp:

50 Hz is just not very good for PID of many subsystems in FRC .

I’d actually say that 50 Hz with proper feedforward gains is adequate for most mechanisms. It’s all teams had for a long time even.

Elevators are one of the simplest mechanisms to control since they’re not very prone to disturbances.

Any team using REV motor controllers is better of using RIO with a profiled PID controller

Honestly, it was just because this was the way we’ve been doing it for a while. I will eventually switch over to the onboard PID for the elevator but this was very abnormal behavior that we’ve never seen before too. Although if I switch it would fix it, I’m worried this would still affect our other subsystems, like the pivoting claw, which I don’t really like running PID on the TalonFX, mostly because of inexperience with it honestly.

Anyways, here is an example of the jitter you would see. (We are 2601 Blue Alliance)

posts.name: Karl Olson
posts.cooked:
You know, fair. I should phrase my point much better.

I see little reason to use the 50 Hz loop on the RIO for PID when it can be offloaded onto a motor controller without need for significant changes. Less precise tuning is needed to maintain stable control and typically cleaner code, especially when all of the TalonFX stuff is set up like in this case.

Yes in most situations it is better to run the pid on the motor controller but this isnt their problem.

Could it be something to do with the two instances of smart dashboard you used to have?

posts.name: Karl Olson
posts.cooked:
0_gottogo_0:

this isnt their problem

xc9zf:

Yeah, a continuation of this post, our elevator would violently jitter and shake

CakeDeer6:

Those loop overruns are really small. As long as they aren’t causing significant issues, it might be best to just ignore them.

Maybe. This might be an XY problem . The elevator jitter is apparently fixed by offloading the PID , so why not just offload the PID ? Small loop overruns sometimes don’t matter at all, especially if they are rare.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
ArchdukeTim:

Any team using REV motor controllers is better of using RIO with a profiled PID controller

The position PID control on the Spark Max/Flex is fine.  It’s the motion profiling that’s scuffed.
